unit_learning_outcomes.description: explain what constitutes unlawful discrimination and how a complaint of unlawful discrimination is pursued within the current regulatory framework
analyse and critique the role of law in addressing inequality and discrimination
critique reform options and proposals in the field of discrimination law
contrast different theoretical approaches to equality and non-discrimination
locate and analyse relevant primary and secondary sources relating to discrimination law

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading textbook and other designed materials
reviewing web content, blogs and related material

enrolment_rules.description: (130cp in Law or LAWS units) or (130cp including LAWS260 or LAWS2060)

assessments.description: On-line quiz based on content covered in the early part of the course

A series of participatory tasks scheduled throughout the semester to monitor student progress and participation in the unit. These may include reflective task, reporting back from a group discussion, participating in role plays, discussions and other exercises, commenting on readings, and contributions to discussions.

This task requires students to engage in in-depth research and reading from a wide range of sources, from which they will develop well-supported arguments. In writing the essay, students will demonstrate their ability to critically analyse the core issues raised by a topic, as well as an understanding of the context, relevant case law, and the broader public policy issues involved.
A timed assessment task for which all unit content may be relevant

data.description: This unit aims to give students a grounding in both the theoretical and practical application of Australia's existing anti-discrimination regulatory framework. The unit introduces students to critical debates regarding what is discrimination, what anti-discrimination legislation is designed to achieve, and how best can law address inequality and discrimination. The unit also examines the legal form in which discrimination is regulated. It requires students to come to terms with the legal concepts of direct and indirect discrimination, the construction of the various grounds of discrimination, the application of the prohibitions in specified contexts, as well as defences and exemptions that apply.
data.title: Discrimination and the Law
